message: @berryp my work switched to convore as our chat room, so we wrote a bot to post funny crap and make fun of people who post dupes

I've just started an Android app myself, purely as a learning exercise to get into Android development. I chose Convore as the target because the API is straight forward enough that I can concentrate on the actual app development.
@leah @ericflo @etmaguire good work on the API by the way.
There are a lot of people working with the API and I'd be interested to learn what people are working on.
@berryp thanks!

@berryp yea totally release early i actually started a java convore api for a client i want to create in the future i have some time next week and hope to have my first complete jar released late next week https://github.com/italiano40/convore-java-api/
I should also say that I have written - and still working on - a re-usable Java library for communicating with the API independently of Android SDK. It mostly uses core Java libraries.
@llimllib I totally agree. I'll aim to get it up soon.
@berryp relase early and often :)
@berryp you should put it on github and open source it :)
@italiano40 I certainly intend to when it's more complete. It's still in it's infancy and I haven't implemented all of the methods yet - only started this weekend ;). I also want good test coverage.
@llimllib Yea, the APIs look good, i don't imagine it'll take too long, i just need to sit down and do it. heh
I'm working on Conveggie a crossplatform GUI client. http://github.com/adsworth/conveggie
I use*
@adsworth I  homebrew's python build, which means I (AFAIK) can't use the wx binaries, and building wx looks to be more of a pain than it's worth
I am planning on working on a convore chrome extension, I figure it'd be fun to build an extension..so why not one for convore.  https://github.com/dgreenfield0/convoreChrome_extension
@dgreenfield *cough* include desktop notification from chrome *cough*
@dgreenfield also good idea is to write a javascript library for convore, then build your chrome extension

@dgreenfield two good reasons to write a library, one you learn the ins and outs of the api and two if people are looking for a library and find yours then they will want to see an app that uses it and it is instant ad for your extension
@dgreenfield Chrome's API is great to work with, should be a fun project
@adsworth if wx wasn't near-impossible to get working on a custom python build on mac, I'd try your app out :(
@llimllib did you overwrite your standard python? or why is the custom python a problem?
@italiano40 thats not a bad idea.  thanks
Sounds like Convore and the API design has helped to inspire a lot of people to learn new technologies :)
@leah @ericflo @etmaguire I think it would be really neat to have a wiki style page linked from (or section on) the API docs listing/detailing projects that are using the API.
@italiano40 def a good idea on the lib.
@italiano40 partially per my developer ADD and it was good idea, iam working on the JS lib.
@dgreenfield Just saw your message today. I started putting something together for a Convore chrome extension and called it 'rex'. Want to join forces? https://github.com/fcarriedo/rex-chrome
@fcarriedo Sounds good to me.
@dgreenfield Within the rex.js there is the very beginning (in diapers) of a convore api js lib. Maybe we can plug the one you're working on.
@fcarriedo yea, i just started throwing some stuff together, but ill take a look and add in what i have.
just released VorePad - convore client for iPad: http://itunes.apple.com/app/vorepad/id432161192?mt=8
@jazzychad That one is neat!
Evilbot! https://github.com/defunkt/evilbot
@jazzychad Nice work. If I had an iPad would be testing it out. Looks good from the screenshots though, like the icon too.

The bot that @llimllib mentioned is at https://github.com/markolson/linkbot, if anyone is interested. It can get a little messy at time, but all responders are implemented as plugins and all of the plugins can interact with one another, so you can create a beautiful spaghetti bot infrastructure!
As well as the python version I made for testing: https://github.com/llimllib/pyphage
Anybody working on a C lib.  *Is thinking about a pidgin plugin as well.
Anybody working a native Mac app?
I am
@protocool i'm glad to hear that. Is it going to be built into Propane or separate app? No eta or project site yet, right?

@MikeT I originally intended to incorporate it into Propane2 and I'd still really prefer that. But the first (limited release) pass will be something that just talks to convore but can still easily integrate Campfire. Assuming the feedback I get doesn't require changing the UI conventions too far away from typical campfire usage then I'll integrate Propane2's campfire code and call it Propane2. Otherwise, it'll end up as 2 products.
@protocool Thank you for the information, I really appreciate it. I can't wait to see it in action.
@bat I was thinking of making one so sites could put there forums on there and then just install a web app but I jus don't have time
is there an alternate open source web client yet?

@italiano40 That is a good suggestion. Mercurial or Git, both are great VCS. I think that it is not going to make a difference in the Delphi community right now, but in the middle term, Github should be better.

We (@norbux and I) are making a client called Conboard using Delphi XE, and we intend to publish it soon as open source (on bitbucket). Our goal is to get it to the spanish and latinamerican Delphi community, maybe set user groups over Convore, and join forces in this little project.
@salvadorhgr advice put it on github you will get more users looking at it, i know that bitbucket is a deal breaker for me to check out a project js
Maybe is not so useful as a Js lib but it could evolve to a DLL, maybe use the announced capabilities of the next Delphi version (compiling to native Mac, Linux, Win32 and Win64)... ;)
We recently created the tarpipe Convore connector, that lets you post messages from any tarpipe workflow: http://blog.tarpipe.com/2011/04/20/convore-connector/
